Introduction

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is a primary immunodeficiency disorder that occurs due to an X-linked recessive mutation in the WAS gene.  Classically, patients develop combined cellular and humoral immunodeficiency, microthrombocytopenia, and eczema.

Pathogenesis and clinical presentation



WAS occurs due to an X-linked recessive mutation in the WAS gene, which is expressed exclusively in hematopoietic cells.  The WAS gene encodes a protein (WAS protein) involved in cell structure and cell-to-cell interactions.  Specifically, the WAS protein induces actin polymerization that allows T-helper cells (CD4+) to interact with antigen-presenting cells (eg, macrophages).  Without this interaction, T-helper cells (CD4+) cannot recognize the antigen and coordinate the adaptive immune response by stimulating B-cell proliferation and differentiation into antibody-producing plasma cells and memory cells.



Due to the mutation in the WAS gene, patients develop combined cellular and humoral immunodeficiency, leading to an increased risk for recurrent viral, bacterial, and fungal infections.  Patients with WAS are particularly susceptible to infection with encapsulated organisms (eg, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus influenzae), which commonly presents as otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia.



In addition, patients are at increased risk for immune dysregulation that can lead to eczema, autoimmune diseases, and malignancies.  Patients often have a chronic, severely pruritic form of eczema.  Autoimmune diseases commonly associated with WAS include immune-mediated cytopenias and vasculitides.  Patients are at particularly increased risk for non-Hodgkin lymphoma.



Finally, the WAS protein is also involved in thrombocytopoiesis, and patients develop microthrombocytopenia (reduced platelet size and number) due to platelet cytoskeletal abnormalities.  They are at increased risk for hemorrhage that ranges from mild mucosal bleeding to severe intracranial bleeding.  Thrombocytopenia is present at birth and may cause excessive bleeding from the umbilical stump or circumcision site.



Therefore, the classic triad of WAS includes:



  • Recurrent viral, bacterial, and fungal infections
  • Eczema
  • Hemorrhage (eg, petechiae, purpura, hematemesis, epistaxis)


WAS most commonly presents in late infancy or early childhood because maternal antibodies wane after the first few months of life.  The presence and severity of the classic triad of symptoms varies depending on the underlying genetic mutation.  Mutations that result in absent WAS protein production are associated with severe phenotypes (eg, classic triad with autoimmune complications).  Similarly, mutations that result in reduced WAS protein production are associated with mild phenotypes (eg, isolated eczema or bleeding).

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected WAS, initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Complete blood count with differential:  shows thrombocytopenia.  The absolute lymphocyte count is typically normal in infancy but decreases later in life due to impaired lymphocyte proliferation.
  • Peripheral blood smear:  demonstrates small platelets.
  • Quantitative immunoglobulin analysis is variable but often shows normal-to-low IgG and IgM.  In contrast, IgA and IgE are often elevated.


Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis by identifying the underlying mutation.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for WAS includes other immunologic conditions, such as:



  • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID):  Similar to WAS, SCID is most commonly caused by an X-linked recessive mutation that leads to combined cellular and humoral immunodeficiency.  However, patients typically experience recurrent infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.  Eczema and thrombocytopenia are not common.
  • Job syndrome (hyper-IgE syndrome):  This condition presents with recurrent infections (eg, cutaneous, pulmonary) and eczema, but thrombocytopenia is not seen.
  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura:  This form of immune-mediated thrombocytopenia typically occurs due to autoantibody production following a viral illness.  Platelet size is normal or large, in contrast to the small platelets seen in WAS.  Patients typically do not develop immunodeficiency or eczema.
  • Ataxia telangiectasia syndrome:  This condition is associated with B- and T-cell deficiency, similarly to WAS; however, telangiectasia (not eczema) is the associated cutaneous finding.

Management



Management of WAS requires a multidisciplinary approach, including treatment of the following:



  • Immunodeficiency:  Prophylactic antimicrobials (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, acyclovir) are used.  Intravenous immunoglobulin may be considered for patients with significant humoral immunodeficiency.
  • Thrombocytopenia:  Platelet transfusions may be necessary to prevent acute bleeding, especially prior to surgical procedures.  Thrombopoietin receptor agonists may be considered in severe cases.  Antiplatelet medications (eg, aspirin) should be avoided.
  • Eczema:  Topical emollients should be applied daily with corticosteroids as needed for exacerbations.


Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is curative, and if performed early, significantly reduces morbidity and mortality.  Patients should be closely monitored for complications, including autoimmune diseases and malignancies.

Prognosis



Untreated WAS is associated with a poor prognosis due to recurrent infections, autoimmune diseases, hemorrhage, and malignancies.  Early HSCT significantly improves survival rates.
